description: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a clonal hematopoietic malignancy, characterized by expansion of immature leukemic blasts in the bone marrow. In AML, specific tyrosine kinases have been implicated in leukemogenesis, and are associated with poor treatment outcome. However, targeted therapy using kinase inhibitors (KIs) has had limited success, and may be improved by proper patient selection. We performed phosphotyrosine (pY) based, label-free phosphoproteomics to identify hyperphosphorylated, active kinases in two FLT3+ AML Pt samples.

keywords.name: submitter keyword
keywords.value: Human, Tyrosine kinase, Acute Myeloid Leukemia, AML, label-free, FLT3, single-shot, phosphoproteomics

terms.name: Reference
terms.value: van Alphen C, Cloos J, Beekhof R, Cucchi DGJ, Piersma SR, Knol JC, Henneman AA, Pham TV, van Meerloo J, Ossenkoppele GJ, Verheul HM, Janssen JJ, Jimenez CR. Phosphotyrosine-based phosphoproteomics for target identification and drug response prediction in AML cell lines. Mol Cell Proteomics. 2020

title: The phosphoproteomic landscape of two FLT3+ Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) patient samples.
